markdownRemark.html:
Score: 29.5

perezhilton.com  (WEB - en-US)

A gossip website known for its biting and sometimes inaccurate celebrity coverage.

Proceed with caution: This website severely violates basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Perezhilton.com appears to be owned by the website’s founder, Perez Hilton. Hilton, whose real name is Mario Armando Lavandeira Jr., is a celebrity gossip blogger and media personality. In addition to his popular website, Hilton has published a book, hosted television and radio shows, and occasionally appears as a guest on reality shows such as Celebrity Big Brother and Worst Cooks in America.

Forbes reported in March 2017 that the site earned approximately $575,000 a month in advertising. In 2010, Gawker reported that gossip bloggers Zack Taylor and Nik Richie had offered $20 million to buy perezhilton.com.

Hilton did not respond to two NewsGuard emails asking if he is the current or sole owner of perezhilton.com.

Content

Perezhilton.com is a celebrity gossip and news site closely tied to the persona of Perez Hilton. Content categories include Gay Gay Gay, Donald Trump, Viral: News, Taylor Swift, Kanye West, Kim Kardashian, LGBT, Politik, and Exclusives. Headlines are overheated in tone, often presented as gossipy questions followed by a large “CLICK FOR DETAILS” bar. Typical headlines include, “SHADY! Paris Hilton Taking Jabs At Kim Kardashian With Her Newest Posts??” and “MARC VS. RIHANNA: Jacobs’ NYFW Show Ran Late -- Was It On Purpose To Spite RiRi?”

Perezhilton.com also frequently runs stories that present President Trump and his supporters in a negative light, such as, “Donald Trump Ordered The Braille Be Removed From His Elevators. ‘No Blind People are Going to Live in Trump Tower,’” and “Kanye West Gets Booed After Launching Into Pro-Trump Speech On ‘SNL’!”

Credibility

Most articles on perezhilton.com are drawn from other news sites. Sources for information and images are typically credited, and links to outside media sources are embedded in articles.

Perezhilton.com’s exclusive stories are sometimes based on anonymous sources. Although the site’s exclusives -- particularly its “first looks” at movie trailers and other promotional materials -- often prove correct, the site has published “scoops” that turned out to be wrong. In August 2007, for example, Perezhilton.com ran two stories reporting incorrectly that former Cuban president Fidel Castro had died. The stories were still on the site in October 2018, and they do not appear to ever have been corrected. Castro died almost a decade later, in 2016.

In September 2009, Hilton reported, incorrectly, that Charlie’s Angels actress Jaclyn Smith had attempted suicide. The headline was later updated to describe Smith as “Alive and Well!”

The site regularly mixes opinion and speculation into its news coverage. A September 2018 story “Watch Rubio & Alex Jones Get In Heated Argument Outside Tech Hearing,” for example, is accompanied with an image bearing the words “Trash vs Dumpster Fire!” Another September article is titled “Trump & White House Can’t Decide Whether To Lie About Secret Resister!” (The headline refers to an op-ed published in the New York Times that month by an anonymous Trump administration insider claiming to be part of “the Resistance.”)

Misleading headlines are not hard to find. A September 2018 article is teased with the description “KIM KARDASHIAN GOING BACK TO SCHOOL? Kanye West Says Kim ‘Is In Law School Now.’” However, the article makes it clear that Kardashian is not actually attending law school and that West was joking. Another article in September was titled “Ashley Benson Leaves Flirty Comments on Cara Delevigne’s Instagram Photo! Did Ashley Benson Just Confirm Her Relationship With Cara Delevigne!?” However, the article itself reported that comments attributed to Benson were the result of a hack.

Perezhilton.com does not articulate a corrections policy and NewsGuard did not find evidence that it runs corrections. Hilton did not respond to two NewsGuard emails asking about the site’s approach to corrections.

Because Perezhilton.com often bases its reports on anonymous sources, does not apparently have a process for correcting mistakes, presents speculation mixed in with news, and does not indicate to readers that it has a political agenda yet consistently advances an anti-Trump point of view, NewsGuard has determined that the site does not gather and present news responsibly and does not adequately handle the difference between news and opinion.

Hilton did not respond to two NewsGuard emails asking about the site’s editorial standards, its mixing of opinion and news, and its headlines.

Transparency

Articles generally do not include the name of the writer, and the site gives the impression that virtually all of the articles are written by Hilton himself. Perezhilton.com is staffed with writers and editors, although they are not named on the site. A NewsGuard LinkedIn search found four current perezhilton.com editorial staff, none of whom is named anywhere on the site.

Although Hilton is presumably the site’s owner, the site’s ownership is never explicitly disclosed.

Advertisements on perezhilton.com are clearly distinguished from editorial content.

The site’s About page includes an email address to contact Hilton directly. Hilton did not respond to two NewsGuard emails sent to that address asking about its lack of disclosure about its ownership, leadership, and content creators.

History

Hilton began blogging in 2004. His site was named PageSixSixSix until he was threatened with legal action by the New York Post, which publishes a famous gossip section and site called Page Six. Hilton took on his pen name -- a play on the name of media personality Paris Hilton -- after receiving death threats for referring to then-closeted singer Clay Aiken as “Clay Gay-kin.”

Hilton became notorious in the 2000s for his scathing reporting on celebrities and for outing celebrities. He has repeatedly been sued for libel or threatened with legal action, but the cases were largely either settled or dismissed.

Written by:
Bron Maher

Edited by:
Anna-Sophie Harling Eric Effron
